entry.title: Upgrade openssl in Ubuntu and CentOS
entry.summary:
Upgrade OpenSSL in Ubuntu and CentOS

Hope you know about openssl heartbleed bug. Don't know about, no problem go through it http://heartbleed.com/ . The point here is you should upgrade your openssl. Because of this bug all linux variants release the patch for openssl. Here the steps for upgrade openssl both ubuntu and centos.

How to find I am using affected version...?

In ubuntu:

Run this command

openssl version -a

There you can find "built on" date. If that date is older than Apr 7. Then you are using older version. You should upgrade your version.

OpenSSL 1.0.1 14 Mar 2012
built on: Wed Jan 8 20:45:51 UTC 2014

In CentOS:

Same as above.

How to upgrade openssl..?

In Ubuntu:

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install libssl1.0.0 openssl -y

In CentOS:

sudo yum update
sudo yum update openssl -y

How to check am I upgarded..?

openssl version -a | grep built

The date should greater than or equal to Apr 7.

Hey..!!! you are done. Happy secure linuxing... ðŸ˜„

entry.title: Automount vmware shared folder in ubuntu
entry.summary:
How to fix shared folder automount problem in vmware ..?

I am using vmware player for last several years. But I am not tested their shared folder features. To share your host os folder with vm you have to install "vmware tools" on guest os. Installing vmware tools is very simple.

Checking vmware module :

sudo lsmod | grep vmhgfs

It should return some values something like shown on image.

List modules

If not you have to install vmware tools.

Installing vmware tools :

  • Goto Player â†’ Manage â†’ Install vmware Tools . Now Vmware Tools is mounted as CDROM with in VM

Install VMware Tools

  • Extract Your VmwareTools-9.2.0-799703.tar.gz file to somewhere.
  • Goto "vmware-tools-distrib" folder path in terminal
  • Then run this command "./vmware-install.pl"
  • Just press enter for all the questions asked while installing

Vmware Install

Add shared folder for VM:

  • Goto Player â†’ Manage â†’ Virtual Machine Settings
  • In Options tab you can find the Shared Folders

Shared Folder

  • Then reboot your machine

Auto mount shared folder on startup:

Finally I came back to point. After restarted the shared folder are not shown with in "/mnt/hgfs/" folder. So here is the fix for that.

There is a startup script called "open-vm-tools" with in /etc/init.d/ folder. Just add the below line in the start function.

mount -t vmhgfs .host:/ /mnt/hgfs

Then restart the service "sudo service open-vm-tools restart".

open-vm-tools startup

My Environmental :

Product : Vmware Player version 5.0.0 build-812388
Vmware Tools: VmwareTools-9.2.0-799703
Guest OS : Ubuntu 12.04 LTS 32 bit
Host OS : Windows 7 64 bit
